speaker: Apiza
text: Hello!

speaker: Apiza
text: I am Apiza, an automated virtual assistant supervised by a human.

speaker: Apiza
text: I look forward to helping you today!

speaker: Programmer
text: Hi Apiza,

speaker: Programmer
text: can you explain how to create a new ssh session?

speaker: Apiza
text: Sure!

speaker: Apiza
text:
It looks like the best way to create a new ssh session is with 

ssh_session ssh_new	(	void 		)

speaker: Apiza
text: Description\nCreate a new ssh session.

speaker: Programmer
text: is that a void method or does it return anything?

speaker: Apiza
text: This method returns an "ssh_session":\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns\nA new ssh_session pointer, NULL on error.

speaker: Programmer
text: how do I connect to localhost once I've created a new ssh_session?

speaker: Apiza
text: This looks like the best method to connect:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: int ssh_connect\t(\tssh_session session\t)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Description 
Connect to the ssh server.

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters 
session: The ssh session to connect.

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns \nSSH_OK on success, SSH_ERROR on error. \nSSH_AGAIN, if the session is in nonblocking mode, and call must be done again.

speaker: Apiza
text: The only method I found involving "localhost" is ssh_options_getopt:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
int ssh_options_getopt	(	ssh_session 	session,
int * 	argcptr,
char ** 	argv 
)

speaker: Apiza
text:
Description
Parse command line arguments.
This is a helper for your application to generate the appropriate options from the command line arguments.
The argv array and argc value are changed so that the parsed arguments wont appear anymore in them.
The single arguments (without switches) are not parsed. thus, myssh -l user localhost
The command wont set the hostname value of options to localhost.

speaker: Programmer
text: for the ssh_connect() method, shouldn't I provide a username and password to connect to an ssh server?

speaker: Apiza
text: The ssh_connect method doesn't seem to mention a username field or a password field.

speaker: Apiza
text: The function ssh_userauth_password may be appropriate:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
Apiza
text:
Description
Try to authenticate by password.
This authentication method is normally disabled on SSHv2 server. You should use keyboard-interactive mode.
The 'password' value MUST be encoded UTF-8. It is up to the server how to interpret the password and validate it against the password database. However, if you read the password in some other encoding, you MUST convert the password to UTF-8.

speaker: Programmer
text: for the ssh_connect() method, can you tell me what the int values are for SSH_OK, SSH_ERROR and SSH_AGAIN?

speaker: Apiza
text: Sure

speaker: Apiza
text: it looks like these are the "Error return codes":\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
/* Error return codes */
 #define SSH_OK 0 /* No error */
 #define SSH_ERROR -1 /* Error of some kind */
 #define SSH_AGAIN -2 /* The nonblocking call must be repeated */
 #define SSH_EOF -127 /* We have already a eof */

speaker: Programmer
text: and for the ssh_userauth_password() method, does that only tell you if the provided authentication is valid or will it connect to the server as well?

speaker: Apiza
text: You must be connected to the server before using ssh_userauth_password. \n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
ssh_userauth_password returns

SSH_AUTH_ERROR: A serious error happened.
SSH_AUTH_DENIED: Authentication failed: use another method
SSH_AUTH_PARTIAL: You've been partially authenticated, you still have to use another method
SSH_AUTH_SUCCESS: Authentication success
SSH_AUTH_AGAIN: In nonblocking mode, you've got to call this again later.

speaker: Apiza
text: Note\nMost server implementations do not permit changing the username during authentication. The username should only be set with ssh_options_set() only before you connect to the server.

speaker: Programmer
text: can you give me the int values for those codes?

text: Sure!\n\n

text: how would I create and open a new ssh channel in an existing ssh session?

speaker: Apiza
text: It looks like ssh_channel ssh_channel_new\t(\tssh_session \tsession\t) will help create a new ssh channel. \n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Description
Allocate a new channel.

speaker: Apiza

speaker: Apiza
text:
Description
Allocate a new channel.

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters

speaker: Apiza
text:

A pointer to a newly allocated channel, NULL on error.

speaker: Apiza
text: References ssh_buffer_free(), and ssh_buffer_new().

speaker: Programmer

speaker: Programmer
text: and whats the difference between ssh_channel_open_auth_agent and ssh_channel_open_session

speaker: Apiza
text:
ssh_channel_open_auth_agent:

Description
Open an agent authentication forwarding channel.
This type of channel can be opened by a server towards a client in order to provide SSH-Agent services to the server-side process. This channel can only be opened if the client claimed support by sending a channel request beforehand.

speaker: Apiza
text:
ssh_channel_open_session:

Description
Open a session channel (suited for a shell, not TCP forwarding).

speaker: Apiza
text: ssh_channel_open_session seems to be the more popular function.

speaker: Programmer
text: and how would I execute a command on an opened channel?

speaker: Apiza
text: This method should work:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
Apiza
text:
Description
Run a shell command without an interactive shell.
This is similar to 'sh -c command'.

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters
channel: The channel to execute the command.
cmd: The command to execute (e.g. "ls ~/ -al | grep -i reports").

speaker: Apiza
text:
Returns
SSH_OK on success, SSH_ERROR if an error occurred, SSH_AGAIN if in nonblocking mode and call has to be done again.

speaker: Apiza
Programmer
text: what is buffer in that code sample?

speaker: Programmer
text: just a char *?

speaker: Apiza
text: The buffer variable used in ssh_channel_read is a void *\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
int ssh_channel_read	(	ssh_channel 	channel,
void * 	dest,
uint32_t 	count,
int 	is_stderr 
)

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters
channel: The channel to read from.
dest: The destination buffer which will get the data.
count: The count of bytes to be read.
is_stderr: A boolean value to mark reading from the stderr flow.

speaker: Programmer
text: how do I shut down a channel?

speaker: Programmer
text: specifically by sending an eof?

speaker: Apiza
text: One of those methods may help:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: int ssh_channel_close\t(\tssh_channel \tchannel\t)\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Description
Close a channel.
This sends an end of file and then closes the channel. You won't be able to recover any data the server was going to send or was in buffers.

speaker: Apiza
text: void ssh_channel_free\t(\tssh_channel \tchannel\t)\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Description\nClose and free a channel.

speaker: Apiza
text: To send an eof, you may use int ssh_channel_send_eof\t(\tssh_channel \tchannel\t)

speaker: Programmer
text: does ssh_channel_close also free the channel?

speaker: Apiza
text: ssh_channel_close only closes the channel.

speaker: Apiza
text: ssh_channel_free closes and frees the channel.

speaker: Programmer
text: nevermind I figured it out

speaker: Apiza
text: I am glad to hear it!

speaker: Programmer

text:

Start a new sftp session.

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters
session: The ssh session to use.

Returns
A new sftp session or NULL on error.
